thread.title: Business Breakfast LIVE: North Sea discovery by energy giant could unlock 130 million barrels of oil

author: Coreena Ford
title: Business Breakfast LIVE: North Sea discovery by energy giant could unlock 130 million barrels of oil
text:
Coreena Ford Fastest 50: Sunderland's Puregas Solutions named North East's fastest growing company 
Renewable energy company Puregas Solutions was the major winner at the 2017 Ward Hadaway Fastest 50 Awards – the 20th in the event’s history. 
The Sunderland-based company won the award for the overall fastest growing North East business of 2017, as well as being named the fastest growing medium-sized business in the region. 
Puregas Solutions specialises in delivering efficient and reliable biogas upgrading solutions using its own CApture process. 
The technology enables the company to upgrade raw biogas to biomethane/Renewable Natural Gas for direct injection into the gas grid, compression for vehicle fuelling (bioCNG) or liquefied to provide bioLNG (liquefied natural gas) – all forms of low carbon fuel. 
Steven Scott, sales manager at Puregas Solutions, said: “It’s fantastic to win this award and we are very, very proud. 
“We had inkling we had done well but we didn’t expect to have won.” 
The Wearside business fought off competition from Guisborough-based FJ Booth Construction Ltd and Newcastle-based intuitive software application developer Scott Logic to win the fastest growing medium-sized business award, for companies with annual turnover of between £7.5 and £15m. 
The other winners at the Ward Hadaway Fastest 50 Awards for 2017 were Gateshead’s Bentincks Ltd and Stockton-based Transflex Vehicle Rental. Fastest Fifty Awards at the Baltic. Winners overall Puregas Solutions (Image: newcastle chronicle) 9.14 KEY EVENT Harvey Weinstein's dismissal explained 
As news filters out from Hollywood amid Harvey Weinstein’s immediate dismissal from the company he co-founded, this video explains the story. 9.12 Coreena Ford Ireland's female entrepreneurs told to treat Brexit like any business risk 
Ireland’s business development agency is encouraging female entrepreneurs to ramp up exports to the UK, saying Brexit should be approached like any other business risk. 
Sarita Johnston, female entrepreneurship manager at Enterprise Ireland (EI), rejected suggestions that it may be irresponsible to urge small businesses to expand trade with Britain while post-Brexit arrangements are still in up in the air. 
Brexit uncertainty, she said, is just one more factor to consider when female entrepreneurs are scaling up their business. 
“The economics of trade are continuously changing. Trade is cyclical, and no matter what environment we are, there continue to be barriers to trade,” she said. 
“Nobody knows what Brexit means but we do know that market trends and market environments and market economics change on a daily basis. 
“What we have tried to do at Enterprise Ireland is to potentially identify the greatest area of where there will need to be more support for companies going forward,” she explained. 9.05 Coreena Ford Crystal Maze-style business launched by Newcastle father-of-two 
A creative father-of-two has turned a hobby into a Crystal Maze-style business, taking fun and games into buildings and homes around the region. 
Jim Gillon is the brains behind Enigma Mobile, a Newcastle company operating across the North East serving up team-based challenge events that can be set up in almost any venue, including businesses, homes and workplaces. 
He was inspired to create the company after several years of staging successful parties at home, influenced by the popular Channel 4 game show and the rise of experiences like escape rooms, where players are locked in a room and have to escape by solving puzzles and logic problems. 
The two-man team stages parties for grown-ups and children as well as corporate events. 
Mr Gillon, of Heaton, Newcastle said: “Escape rooms are becoming increasingly popular, as folk shun digital tech and screens, going back to real-life experiences for their enjoyment. 
He first came up with the idea for Enigma Mobile nine years ago. 
He said: “This all came about years ago when my partner Kirsty was pregnant with our first child and we couldn’t really go out. I’d turn our house into the Crystal Maze and we’d get all of our friends round, and we’d all have a great time.” Jim Gillon who runs a business offering crystal maze style games (Image: Newcastle Chronicle) 9.00 KEY EVENT 'I was homeless at 16 and now I'm a CEO': meet Streetwise's leader Mandy Coppin 
It is traditional for firms to hold events to celebrate a big anniversary, but not many can say their chief executive led a squadron of planes down the Tyne to mark 25 years in business. 
But then Mandy Coppin, head of youth charity Streetwise, isn’t your usual chief executive. 
Mandy has spent her entire career working in the voluntary and community sector, set up community services that have helped thousands of people and she also happens to be a fully qualified pilot and women’s self-defence instructor. 
As leader of Streetwise, she heads up a team of 24 people which has provided free, confidential and non-judgmental information and advice support services to more than 300,000 people since 1991. And she is one CEO the 15,000-plus young service users who turn to Streetwise each year can relate to: she was homeless at 16. Mandy Coppin in her plane, flying the Tyne for the 25th anniversary of Streetwise (Image: Mandy Coppin) 8.55 Coreena Ford Amazon UK makes bid for rural business 
Amazon is making inroads into the UK countryside as part of plans to “double down” on the untapped potential of rural and farming communities. 
The retail giant has already started working with businesses ranging from a furniture retailer in Dumfries, Scotland, to a tech firm offering cow tracking devices as part of that strategy, and has launched a major research project looking at how rural firms can harness the internet to ramp up growth. 
Britain’s rural economy is “actually a lot bigger than people realise,” Doug Gurr, Amazon’s UK country manager said. 
“There’s now well over 530,000 rural businesses which is roughly 24% of the UK total, so it’s a big chunk of the economy, far more than you might think in a world in which we always assume everything is urbanised.” 
A recent survey showed that 10,000 rural British sellers - including small business and individuals - are using the Amazon Marketplace to grow their business, but the retail giant is interested in reaching more entrepreneurs. 
“This is a specific initiative that we’ve chosen to double down on,” he said. 
Mr Gurr will be making his way to Birmingham at the start of November where 6,000 businesses are set to descend on the Rural Entrepreneur Show. 
There, the company will launch a new two-day Amazon Academy, where attendees will be offered advice from seasoned rural e-commerce entrepreneurs as well as senior Amazon experts on how to grow revenue online through the Amazon Marketplace and reach customers through its cloud voice service, Alexa. Mr Gurr admitted that Amazon has a commercial interest behind bringing companies online, but suggested there were larger benefits. 
“It’s an area we’re passionate about, and some of it is in light of self-interest, but we’re very passionate particularly about helping small and medium sized businesses to succeed and export.” Hadrian's Wall above Cawfield Quarry - Amazon is making a bid for more rural business. (Image: David Head) 8.51 Coreena Ford Trinity Mirror sees 'improving trends' as Daily Express buyout talks continues 
The publisher of the Chronicle, Journal and Sunday Sun as well as national newspaper the Daily Mirror has posted a decline in third-quarter revenue as talks to acquire Daily Express owner Northern & Shell continue. 
Trinity Mirror revealed an 8% fall in like-for-like revenue in the period as publishing revenue fell by 9% and print declined by 10%. 
Print advertising and circulation revenue fell by 16% and 7% respectively, although digital revenue grew 4%. 
The group said it is experiencing“improving trends” in nationally sourced print advertising revenues, but added that local advertising, particularly classified, remains “challenging and volatile”. 
Last month the firm confirmed discussions were under way to buy Northern & Shell, which also houses the Daily Star. 
The firm said: “Further to the announcement made on 8 September 2017, the group continues to make progress on discussions to acquire 100% of the publishing assets of Northern & Shell. Further updates will be made when appropriate.” 
Northern & Shell is owned by Richard Desmond, who acquired the titles in 2000 for £125 million, although it is unclear how much a deal would be worth today. 
The print media industry is grappling with a decline in print advertising and any combination could herald cost savings and a shared cut of a larger advertising pool. 8.45 Coreena Ford Harvey Weinstein sacked by Weinstein Company amid sexual harassment claims 
Harvey Weinstein has been dismissed from the Weinstein Company with immediate effect “in light of new information about misconduct”, the board of directors has announced. 
The Hollywood studio had launched an inquiry into allegations of sexual harassment concerning the Academy Award-winning producer, who is one of its founders. 
A statement from the Weinstein Company Board of Representatives said: “In light of new information about misconduct by Harvey Weinstein that has emerged in the past few days, the directors of The Weinstein Company - Robert Weinstein, Lance Maerov, Richard Koenigsberg and Tarak Ben Ammar - have determined, and have informed Harvey Weinstein, that his employment with The Weinstein Company is terminated, effective immediately.” 
Harvey Weinstein, who was co-chairman of the studio, had previously announced he was taking leave of absence after claims were made by women with whom he had worked. 
The departure leaves Weinstein’s brother Bob, a co-chairman, and chief operating officer David Glasser at the helm of the company 
The money and the power behind some of the biggest Hollywood films of the past 25 years, Weinstein and brother Bob founded Miramax in 1979, building it into a major Hollywood player before selling it to Disney in 1993. 
They continued to work for the firm until 2005 when they quit to set up the Weinstein Company, which spawned hits including The King’s Speech, Django Unchained and Silver Linings Playbook. Film producer Harvey Weinstein.
